FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1889.

OUR NORTHERN INDIANS.

Mr. Dewdney gives constant evidence of the wisdom of Sir John Macdonald in appointing him to the important position he now occupies. Both as Minister of the Interior and as Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs, he has appeared to be guided by the wishes and requirements of the people of the Northwest. He has acted very promptly with regard to the Northern Indians of this District and we have reason to believe that they will be treated justly and fairly by the Government; but we would point out to the latter that most of those Indians have belonged inside of what is known as the ceded territory ever since 1876, and are consequently entitled to all the privileges there since that date, and the money should be paid to them whether they demand it or not. If they do not ask for it, it is only because they are ignorant of what they are entitled to. Another matter to which we would direct the attention of the Minister is the limits of the treaty which is now being made. We are informed that it is not intended to extinguish the Indians or Half-breed title to the lands covered by the provincial district of Saskatchewan. This is a mistake. There are in this district and elsewhere in the Territories and Manitoba large numbers of half-breeds who are entitled to scrip, but cannot get it, because the tribe to whom they were residents of that Territory extending north of Saskatchewan as far as Isola Cross. In most cases that was only temporarily their residence. These claims should be dealt with at once. There will still be a great number until a settlement of all such claims is effected, and we see no reason why it should not be made.

It would not be necessary to take in a very great extent of territory in order to settle all the claims and the expense in doing so would not be great, as there are very few Indians within that district.

The following is taken from the Winnipeg Sun—

OTTAWA, Feb. 2.—Mardoull, member of Saskatchewan, informs me that the Indians are anxious to make arrangements with the Papage company as would secure the building of the Red River Line of the Canadian Pacific during the summer. The road is to be built and the Saskatchewan bridge before the end of June. The line is ninety miles to build the following year to Prince Albert. Mr. Mardoull is much anxious about the construction of the road. He is urging the Government to establish a post at Prince Albert.

RED DEER HILL.

A meeting to consider the advisability of forming this vicinity into a statutory labor district was held at the school house and was well attended. The question was discussed at length and the greater number of those present were in favor of the formation of the district being formed. Capt. Haynes also spoke and strongly favored the scheme.

The recent fall of snow has covered all the open spaces and made singing difficult.

At a late meeting of the School Board an assessment was appointed at $15 per acre. A special meeting was set for next Tuesday.

The debating society will probably reopen soon.

The weather will be more like this than it is at the end of the winter.

R. H. Haynes, who owns his own farm, has been working hard on his land.

A horse belonging to John Hudson fell into a deep hole near his station, a few days ago, but was rescued by neighbors.

David Ballantyne has a large quantity of oats which weighs 30 pounds per ton.

At the meeting of the Road Committee, held last week, the road was well attended and was a great success.

Capt. Haynes and Mr. Plaistow, who are interested in the building of the road, are looking forward to the prospect of a first-class road in the Province next spring.

Charles Walker, who is working on the road, says that the work is going very smoothly and is in need now than he was last year.

The weather is getting colder, and the temperatures are dropping.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

EDMONTON.

The third chance to use enteries here this season occurred on Friday morning, about nine o'clock, when a light snow shower fell. The weather was very fine.

Freighters to Victoria and Saddle Lake have taken the ice of the river from Fort Saskatchewan to Victoria in several trips, and the road is now open for wagons.

The Regina & Long Lake railway company have returned to Regina from Saddle Lake, and run a trip this over the line. They will probably again drive the grading stakes.

Five weddings took place at St. Albert on Tuesday, Jan. 29th; Miss Page to Mr. Morrison; Miss Gray to Mr. Page; Miss Savard; J. Bellrose to Miss Dumont; J. Corrigan to Miss Brouillard.

The Postmaster General has issued an order that money order and savings bank business shall be conducted on Mondays until 11 o'clock a.m.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News, Jan. 30th.

A game of baseball was played on Saturday afternoon by two picked teams. The weather was beautiful and a good game was indulged in.

Insp. Macpherson passed through here on Thursday last for MacLeod, where he took a trip. He visited the Division, but did not go to Prince Albert. He left for Calgary this morning.

One of the largest assemblies of people ever seen in St. Anne's Church was held there on Saturday evening last to witness the marriage ceremony of the Rev. J. F. Priskin to Miss May Gurney, of the Rectory, Red Ground, M.A., of Cataract, England. At 8.30 the bride arrived leaning on the arm of her father, Capt. Charles Gurney, and Miss Eric Macpherson, who acted as bridesmaid, passed up the aisle to the altar, where they were married by the Rev. J. F. Priskin, M.A. The beautiful ceremony of the church was performed by His Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan, and the Rev. Priskin, in a most impressive manner, after which the bridal party proceeded to the residence of Mr. Gurney, where a few of the friends of the happy couple assembled.

PORT MACLEOD.

From the News, Jan. 31st.

Several men arrived from Regina with Insp. Macpherson.

The town is pretty quiet after the festivities of last week-end.

The Orange Order worked on Tuesday, Jan. 29th, and subsequent weeks no fire and open doors.

The present weather is hard on the cattle. They require more food and there has been none for over a week.

W. F. Gurney, Government Engineer, arrived here yesterday. He has been up to the river to make plans for bridges at MacLeod, Kipp and Lethbridge.

Harry Dunbar ploughed as acre and a half on Tuesday, the 29th inst. This is the first time he has ploughed. Plowing has been possible for the greater part of this month, and is still so.

REGINA.

From the Journal, Jan. 31st.

Market prices remain the same as last week. Wheat $5.50 per bushel, with occasionally a cent or two more paid for choice lots. Butter 50c per pound; eggs 10c each.

A subscriber in British Columbia writes us a very depressing account of the wet, muddy and disagreeable weather that has prevailed there and continues to do so. "A year ago," he says, "it was all in the Northwest as on the Pacific coast, in fact the farmer should never have left his farm, but would have bettered himself in British Columbia."

Comet Wright, of the N.W.M.P., disappeared on Thursday evening. He is supposed to be in Edmonton. He is married man and about 35 years old. On Thursday night he went out saying to his wife that he would be back soon and would drink. On Friday and Saturday patrols were made in the vicinity and continued without effect. No person answering his description was found either trading or on the trail. It is thought that some serious thing might have happened to him while walking in the woods. A search was made for him near the bank the day previous to his disappearance.

TOWN COUNCIL

The Town Council met on Monday evening.

The mayor called the meeting to order at 7 o'clock.

The mayor moved that the council adjourn until next Monday evening at 7 o'clock.

The council then adjourned until Monday evening at 7 o'clock.

The next item was taken up in reading communications. L. R. St. Louis made a call on the mayor and clerk. Mr. St. Louis, as alderman, H. W. Newcomb, the town solicitor, requested payment of the debt in the case of St. Louis vs. Shaw.

The Finance Committee recommended the payment of P. Robertson's account. It had been decided to supply him with a warrant and send him the balance incurred in the late election he won.

The Fire, Water and Light Committee reported that the fire hydrant located at the foot of Main Street was in good condition and would be ready for use when the Fire and Light Committee met and found satisfactory, the account be paid. The report was adopted.

Moved by Davis and Sanderson that the mayor and clerk be authorized to proceed at once in the purchase of a map of the town, for his benefit. Said map to have divided the limits of the town into squares, indicating the number of town lots and quantity of land each subdivision on river lots. Carried.

Couns. Woodman and Mair moved that the collector be directed to keep the collector's roll extended until the 27th inst. Carried.

Moved by Donaldson and Woodman that the committee of Public Works be instructed to get the necessary estimates for the construction of the ferry on the river and report at the next meeting of the council. Carried.

Moved by Donaldson and Mair that the mayor and chairman of the Finance Committee be instructed to confer with the collector to extend the time to three months in payment of their taxes, or collect the same immediately. Also, the clerk of the town through the mayor and chairman, such collateral security as shall satisfy the mayor and chairman of Finance Committee as to payment of said amounts, and the interest to be charged to those who take advantage of the extension of three months, at 1 per cent., for the time allowed and not more than two months. Carried.

Moved by Davis and Sanderson that the clerk of the town be instructed that he, the solicitor, has to look for payment of his accounts for costs in the case of St. Louis vs. Shaw, but the solicitor will withdraw after his discussion.

Coun. Davis contended that Mr. McReynolds was able to pay his taxes as any other taxpayer, and thought the council could well afford to sell some of his personal property.

Coun. Sanderson contended that Mr. McReynolds pay the full amount of his taxes but that longer time should be allowed.

The mayor and couns. Woodman and Mair spoke in favor of the rebate or that the council should deal leniently in the matter. After which the following motion was passed:

Moved by Couns. Donaldson and Woodman that the collector be instructed to take no further action in connection with the case of Mr. Sanderson. Moved by Davis and Mair that the saloon license granted to John Dallas be transferred to Geo. T. Brown on the payment of $50.

COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.

The council went into committee of the whole to consider the appointment of the town clerk.

The discussion on the merits of the several offices in the employ of the last council was resumed. Mr. Davis contended that the town clerk's office was unnecessary, and that the town hall was not needed when some spirited talk was indulged in. Mr. Davis contended that he had the support of the mayor and couns. Davis rose to his feet and tendered his resignation on account of ill health.
